results.adx_keywords: Asiana Airlines;Aviation Accidents and Safety;San Francisco (Calif);Fires and Firefighters
results.byline: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and RAVI SOMAIYA
results.title: 2 Die and Many Are Hurt as Plane Crashes in San Francisco
results.abstract: An Asiana jetliner from South Korea crashed and caught fire, killing two people and injuring more than 180 others.

media.caption: Asiana Flight 214, arriving from Seoul, South Korea, broke apart and burst into flames as it crashed while landing at San Francisco International Airport. The plane’s tail, landing gear and one of its engines were ripped off.
Journalists filled a room at the headquarters of Asiana Airlines, which was established in 1988  and is based in South Korea.
Fire crews worked on an Asiana Airlines jet that crashed on landing at San Francisco International Airport on Saturday.
media.copyright: John Green/San Jose Mercury News, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships;Defense of Marriage Act (1996);Supreme Court;Decisions and Verdicts;California;Windsor, Edith Schlain;Spyer, Thea Clara;Scalia, Antonin;Kennedy, Anthony M
results.title: Supreme Court Bolsters Gay Marriage With Two Major Rulings
results.abstract: The court ruled unconstitutional a 1996 law denying federal benefits to legally married same-sex couples and effectively permitted gay marriage in California.
des_facet: SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, CIVIL UNIONS AND DOMESTIC PARTNERSHIPS

media.caption: Plaintiffs and lawyers in Hollingsworth v. Perry, the California Proposition 8 case, Wednesday on steps of the Supreme Court.
People celebrated outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday after it struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.
Two of the plaintiffs in the Proposition 8 case, Jeffrey Zarrillo, center foreground, and Paul Katami, center right, with one of their lawyers, David Boies, far right, outside the Supreme Court.
Sandra Stier, center left, and Kristin Perry, center right, plaintiffs in the California case, spoke to reporters after the decisions by the Supreme Court were announced in Washington on Wednesday.
Wendy Kennedy, left, embraced her spouse, Deborah Spell, at the Stonewall Inn in New York after the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.
A couple celebrated at City Hall in San Francisco on Wednesday after hearing that the Supreme Court had struck down the Defense of Marriage Act.

results.adx_keywords: Food Network;Deen, Paula;Discrimination;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Today (TV Program);Race and Ethnicity
results.title: Food Network Drops Paula Deen
results.abstract: The network announced Friday that it would not renew Ms. Deen’s contract at the end of June, after she apologized for using racist language.

media.caption: Paula Deen cooking on the “Today” show earlier this year.
Paula Deen issued an apology on a YouTube video on Friday.

results.adx_keywords: Gandolfini, James;Actors and Actresses;Deaths (Obituaries);The Sopranos (TV Program);Television;Movies;Home Box Office;Sopranos, The (TV Program)
results.title: James Gandolfini Is Dead at 51; a Complex Mob Boss in ‘The Sopranos’
results.abstract: Mr. Gandolfini won three Emmy Awards for his lead role as a New Jersey mob kingpin on the HBO drama.

media.caption: James Gandolfini in a scene from "The Sopranos."

results.adx_keywords: medicine and health; Sleep; Medicine and Health
results.title: Cheating Ourselves of Sleep
results.abstract: Failing to get enough sleep night after night can compromise your health and may even shorten your life.

results.adx_keywords: Supreme Court;Voting Rights Act (1965);Voter Registration and Requirements;Discrimination;Southern States (US);Ginsburg, Ruth Bader;Roberts, John G Jr;Decisions and Verdicts;States (US);United States;Blacks
results.title: Supreme Court Invalidates Key Part of Voting Rights Act
results.abstract: The Supreme Court split along ideological lines with its ruling that Congress had not provided adequate justification for subjecting the states, mostly in the South, to federal oversight.

media.caption: Wade Henderson, president and C.E.O. of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, criticized the decision on Tuesday.
Representative John Lewis of Georgia, center left, and Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, right, at a news conference. The Voting Rights Act covered nine states, mostly in the South.
media.copyright: Drew Angerer for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots;Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- );Morsi, Mohamed;Egypt;Muslim Brotherhood (Egypt);Al-Ahram (Egyptian Newspaper);Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
results.title: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Is Taken Into Military Custody
results.abstract: Egypt’s military ousted Mohamed Morsi, the nation’s first freely elected president, suspending the Constitution, installing an interim government and insisting it was representing the will of the people.
des_facet: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT

media.caption: Tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Tahrir Square.

results.adx_keywords: Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever);Southwestern States (US);Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;California;Arizona
results.title: A Disease Without a Cure Spreads Quietly in the West
results.abstract: Valley fever has been labeled “a silent epidemic,” with more than 20,000 cases reported each year, but each case is different, and doctors have yet to find a cure.
org_facet: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

media.caption: Joe Klorman, a retired police officer, before treatment for a severe case of valley fever that affects his brain.
Barbara Ludy can no longer work because of the disease.
The disease puts Todd Schaefer in pain every day.
Doctors are unsure how Kaden Watson, 8, was infected with it.
Some inmates at Avenal State Prison are being transferred because of a risk of valley fever.
Mr. Schaefer, 48, has had serious heart problems, and can no longer drink the wine he and his wife, Tammy, produce.
Ms. Ludy takes several pills a day to treat a serious case of cocci.

results.adx_keywords: Sao Paulo (Brazil);Free Fare Movement;Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots;World Cup 2014 (Soccer);Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);Rio de Janeiro (Brazil);Buses;Brazil
results.title: Thousands Gather for Protests in Brazil’s Largest Cities
results.abstract: What began with small protests against bus-fare increases has evolved into a broader indictment of the country’s high cost of living and lavish new stadium projects.

media.caption: Protesters in São Paulo called for lower public transportation fares.
media.copyright: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

media.caption: Military police sprayed a protester with pepper spray during demonstrations in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on Monday.

results.adx_keywords: Football;New England Patriots;Hernandez, Aaron;Murders and Attempted Murders;Lloyd, Odin;Attleboro (Mass);Massachusetts
results.title: Former Patriots Tight End Is Charged With Murder
results.abstract: The N.F.L. player Aaron Hernandez was charged on Wednesday with the murder of Odin Lloyd, a 27-year-old semipro football player who was found dead on June 17.

media.caption: Hernandez was taken into custody at his home, less than a mile from where a 27-year-old man was found dead.
media.copyright: George Rizer for The Boston Globe, via Getty Images

media.caption: Aaron Hernandez helped lead the Patriots to the Super Bowl two seasons ago.
media.copyright: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

media.caption: The tight end in Attleboro District Court with one of his lawyers, Michael K. Fee, right.
Family members of Odin Lloyd, a semipro football player who was found shot to death less than a mile from Hernandez’s home.
media.copyright: Pool photo by Mike George/Sun Chronicle

results.adx_keywords: Exercise; Medicine and Health; Muscles
results.title: The Scientific 7-Minute Workout
results.abstract: In 12 exercises deploying only body weight, a chair and a wall, it fulfills the latest mandates for high-intensity effort, which essentially combines a long run and a visit to the weight room into about seven minutes of steady discomfort — all of it based on science.

results.adx_keywords: Postal Service (US);Surveillance of Citizens by Government;Pickering, Leslie James
results.title: U.S. Postal Service Logging All Mail for Law Enforcement
results.abstract: A Postal Service program created after anthrax attacks gathers photos of the exterior of every piece of paper mail processed in the nation — about 160 billion pieces last year.

media.caption: Leslie James Pickering, the owner of a bookstore in Buffalo, was targeted by a tracking program from the United States Postal Service.
media.copyright: Brendan Bannon for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Muslim Brotherhood (Egypt);Egypt;Morsi, Mohamed;Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat;Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots;Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
results.title: Mayhem in Cairo as Morsi Backers Fight for Return
results.abstract: At least 30 people have died in clashes between those celebrating the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and those demanding his reinstatement.
des_facet: COUPS D'ETAT AND ATTEMPTED COUPS D'ETAT
MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

media.caption: Supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted Egyptian president, carried a man shot on Friday in Cairo after troops opened fire.
Enormous and defiant protests continued across Cairo.
Mohammed Badie, the Supreme Guide of the Muslim Brotherhood.

results.adx_keywords: Pregnancy and Childbirth;Health Insurance and Managed Care;Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates);United States;Series;Paying Till It Hurts (Series)
results.title: American Way of Birth, Costliest in the World
results.abstract: Maternity care and childbirth cost far more in the United States than in other developed countries, but studies show that their citizens do not have less access to care during pregnancy than Americans.

media.caption: Renée C. Martin, left, and her husband, Mark Willett. “The economics of this system are a mess,” Ms. Martin said.
"Making women choose during labor whether you want to pay $1,000 for an epidural, that didn't seem right." Dr. Dean Coonrod, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at Maricopa Medical Center in Phoenix
media.copyright: Laura Segall for The New York Times

media.caption: "Most insurance companies wouldn't blink at my bill, but it was absurd." Dr. Marguerite Duane, who questioned line items on her hospital bill.

results.adx_keywords: China;Urban Areas;Rural Areas;Area Planning and Renewal;Land Use Policies;Series;Leaving the Land (Series)
results.title: China’s Great Uprooting: Moving 250 Million Into Cities
results.abstract: A 12-year plan to move hundreds of millions of rural residents into cities is intended to spur economic growth, but could have unintended consequences, skeptics warn.

media.copyright: Justin Jin for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Nye, Bill;Science and Technology;Bill Nye the Science Guy (TV Program);Television
results.title: Firebrand for Science, and Big Man on Campus
results.abstract: William Sanford Nye, better known as Bill Nye the Science Guy, has gone from TV host to fierce defender of scientific issues that have been polemicized for religious, political and even economic reasons.

media.caption: Bill Nye portrayed an engineering professor in an episode of the CBS show “Numbers,” with Peter MacNicol. Mr. Nye said his goal as a lecturer and entertainer was to interest young people in science.

results.adx_keywords: Snowden, Edward J;Classified Information and State Secrets;Surveillance of Citizens by Government;United States International Relations;Fugitives;National Security Agency;Russia;China;Hong Kong;Ecuador
results.byline: By PETER BAKER and ELLEN BARRY
results.title: Leaker’s Flight Raises Tension Between U.S. and 3 Nations
results.abstract: The Obama administration escalated its criticism on Monday of Russia, China and Ecuador, the countries that appeared to be protecting Edward J. Snowden, who is wanted on spying charges.

media.caption: With Edward J. Snowden apparently in hiding in Moscow, journalists gathered Monday at the Ecuadorean Embassy there.
media.copyright: James Hill for The New York Times

media.caption: Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, said, “We do not buy the suggestion that China could not have taken action.”
The passenger plane, flight SU 150 to Havana, from Moscow Sheremetyevo airport, on Monday before it took off without Edward J. Snowden.

results.adx_keywords: Asiana Airlines;Aviation Accidents and Safety;San Francisco (Calif);Fires and Firefighters;San Francisco International Airport
results.byline: By NORIMITSU ONISHI, CHRISTOPHER DREW, MATTHEW L. WALD and SARAH MASLIN NIR
results.title: Terror on Jet: Seeing Water, Not Runway
results.abstract: The pilot at the controls on Asiana Flight 214 was said to have had only 43 hours of experience flying a Boeing 777, and an airline spokeswoman said that it was his first time piloting a 777 into San Francisco.

media.caption: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board on Sunday at the scene of the crash of Asiana Airlines Flight 214 at San Francisco International Airport.
The parents of Wang Lin Jia, center, are comforted by parents of other students who were on the Asiana Airlines flight.
The United Airlines domestic terminal, which was crowded a day after the airport was closed.
Deborah Hersman, the transportation safety board chairwoman, and Mayor Edwin M. Lee.

Asiana Flight 214, arriving from Seoul, South Korea, broke apart and burst into flames as it crashed while landing at San Francisco International Airport. The plane’s tail, landing gear and one of its engines were ripped off.

results.adx_keywords: Abortion;Washington (State)
results.title: My Abortion, at 23 Weeks
results.abstract: Second-trimester abortions must remain legal because critical information about fetal health is often not available before then.

results.adx_keywords: Athletics and Sports; Carney, Reeve; Exercise; Heart; McDougall, Christopher; medicine and health; Reduced Shakespeare Company; Medicine and Health
results.title: The 4-Minute Workout
results.abstract: A single, strenuous four-minute workout can effectively improve health and fitness as much as longer workouts can, researchers found. Download the “Well 4-Minute Workout” playlist for your workout.
